ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: learned how to design linkages, and CAMs and basic lagrangian analysis as well is CAD design skills. There were also fun arduino assignments and the final project was chill and interesting.
4-bar mechanism design, kinematic tables for analysis of mechanisms, lagrangian dynamics and virtual work.
I learned about lagrangian dynamics, grashof, gruebler, and kinematics tables.
I learned about mechanisms (how to make and analyze 4 bad mechanisms), and advanced dynamics of these mechanisms.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Doc A is a funny teacher that makes the content interesting! It would have been nice if there were more thorough class notes, or links to textbook readings so that I could easily review the content if I missed class or didn't understand it all the first time.

I wish that the course was a more intensive engineering class with multiple weekly homework problems from the textbook that forced us to learn more intensely and intuitively basic skills in classical mechanism design. Even just design problems using graphical methods on paper would encourage greater understanding of the concepts than replicating them a single time in Solidworks. When Doc A picks up steam getting into the details of explaining the content, he speaks lucidly and makes concepts easy to understand, but not very much time is spent each week diving into new concepts. I wish he held us to a higher standard of understanding, so that we would be rewarded with more practical and conceptual knowledge. 

Although students are often busy with other projects, I also wish that the class emphasized classical mechanisms over arduino for the final project. Surely there are considerations and well-trodden solutions for transforming designs into functioning machines, but they are not taught at Yale, and this class (taught with Doc A's experience) would be the place to teach it.
I think it would be nice if there was still an emphasis on starting the project very early. Then, I think it would be nice to expect a higher fidelity prototype at the end.
The professor is incredible, he keeps you engaged during lecture and cares about your learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES! Doc A is great and its a super fun engineering course.

Yes, this class fills in (or reveals) many of the gaps that are left by MENG325. It is a fun and engaging advanced elective where a surprising amount is taught while keeping stress and workload relatively low. This is the most advanced design class taught here, so if you want design knowledge, this class is a solid springboard from which to launch yourself into the textbook (Norton, and Shigley from 325) and bring yourself to proficiency.
Yes, this course is a great course to precede capstone as it gives you exposure to prototyping mechanism design that is otherwise lacking in the MENG major.
I would recommend it if you want a class that will teach you an intro to design where MENG 185 doesnt.
Yes I would recommend any class taught by Doc A. He is a great professor, you will learn challenging concepts, be engaged in lecture, but not be bogged down by a super extensive workload.
Yes, good class. If you liked 400, you will like this class, just slightly more workload.

extras.title: MENG 425 01 - Adv Design & Analysis of Mach
